postQuizHtml:
If you want to learn more about the galaxy, I recommend you check out this page on National Geographic's website:

Origins of the Universe 101

questionPools.feedbackOnUpgradeHtml: Great work! Now we're going to check out outer space... watch this video on galaxies before continuing to the next section!
questionPools.feedbackOnDowngradeHtml: Dang! Review the Solar System 101 Video, then try again! Nice try though.

questions.questionHtml:
Categorize the planets as either a gas giant or terrestrial.
[Randomize options is OFF.]
[There is no hint for this question.]
questions.feedbackForImperfect: The terrestrial planets are Earth, Mercury, Venus, and Mars. Jupiter, Neptune, Saturn, and Uranus are all gas giants.

questions.questionHtml:
Rank the below planets in order of their size, starting with the smallest.
[Randomize options is ON.]
questions.hintHtml: Jupiter is the biggest planet! So it should be number 4.
questions.feedbackForPerfect:
Correct!

The order, for smallest to largest, is 1. Uranus, 2. Neptune, 3. Saturn, 4. Jupiter. Jupiter is the biggest!
questions.feedbackForImperfect:
That's the wrong order...

The order, for smallest to largest, is 1. Uranus, 2. Neptune, 3. Saturn, 4. Jupiter. Jupiter is the biggest!

questions.questionHtml:
Match the terrestrial planets with the number of moons they have.
[Randomize options is on.]
questions.feedbackForPerfect: Yes! Mars and Earth have moons. Mars with two, and Earth with one. Mercury and Venus don't have any moons! üëç
questions.feedbackForImperfect: Close, but actually Mercury and Venus don't have any moons, while Earth has one and Mars has two. Good try. üëç
